content.name: selector
content.title: Selector
content.oneliner: A filter for selecting elements within the document.
content.details:
A filter for selecting elements within the document.

To construct a selector you can:

  • use an element function
  • filter for an element function with specific fields
  • use a string or regular expression
  • use a <label>
  • use a location
  • call the selector constructor to convert any of the above types into a selector value and use the methods below to refine it

Selectors are used to apply styling rules to elements. You can also use selectors to query the document for certain types of elements.

Furthermore, you can pass a selector to several of Typst's built-in functions to configure their behaviour. One such example is the outline where it can be used to change which elements are listed within the outline.

Multiple selectors can be combined using the methods shown below. However, not all kinds of selectors are supported in all places, at the moment.

Example

#context query(
  heading.where(level: 1)
    .or(heading.where(level: 2))
)

= This will be found
== So will this
=== But this will not.

constructor.name: selector
constructor.title: Construct
constructor.oneliner: Turns a value into a selector.

details.content:
Turns a value into a selector. The following values are accepted:

  • An element function like a heading or figure.
  • A string or regular expression.
  • A <label>.
  • A location.
  • A more complex selector like heading.where(level: 1).
Can be an element function like a heading or figure, a <label> or a more complex selector like heading.where(level: 1).

scope.name: or
scope.title: Or
scope.oneliner: Selects all elements that match this or any of the other selectors.

details.content: Selects all elements that match this or any of the other selectors.

scope.name: and
scope.title: And
scope.oneliner: Selects all elements that match this and all of the other selectors.

details.content: Selects all elements that match this and all of the other selectors.

scope.name: before
scope.title: Before
scope.oneliner: Returns a modified selector that will only match elements that occur before the first match of `end`.

details.content: Returns a modified selector that will only match elements that occur before the first match of end.
The original selection will end at the first match of end.
Whether end itself should match or not. This is only relevant if both selectors match the same type of element. Defaults to true.

scope.name: after
scope.title: After
scope.oneliner: Returns a modified selector that will only match elements that occur after the first match of `start`.

details.content: Returns a modified selector that will only match elements that occur after the first match of start.
The original selection will start at the first match of start.
Whether start itself should match or not. This is only relevant if both selectors match the same type of element. Defaults to true.
